page.title: 04Local History _ Pencombe
page.content: At Domesday Pencombe was an important manor of 15 hides probably roughly equivalent to the modern parish. It seems likely that each hide already had its own settlement of which Pencombe was the most important. In the 14th c. settlements were recorded at Barnstone, Church House, Durstone, Fishpool, Maidenhyde, Nash, Sparrington, Stone and Wootton with an average holding of 40 acres. In 1808 a limited common field system was still operating and the Arkwrights bought the Hampton Court estate, to which they were to add much of Pencombe and which they did not dispose of again until 1911. The village green has a war memorial and an oak planted to celebrate Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee. Apart from Pencombe the rest of the original hides are now 200 acre farms with just farmhouse & buildings.
